posts.title: Vertigo
posts.excerpt: Review One of Hitchcock’s most discussed films. Retired police detective Stewart, who has a fear of heights, is hired by old school chum in San Francisco to keep an eye on his wife (Novak), eventually falls in love with his quarry and that’s just the beginning; to reveal more would be unthinkable. posts._title: Shuji Terayama – Tomato Kecchappu Kôtei aka Emperor Tomato Ketchup (1971)
posts.title: Tomato Kecchappu Kôtei
posts.excerpt: Synopsis EMPEROR TOMATO KETCHUP is Terayama’s epic, sexually revolutionary and hallucinatory work from 1972 in which magical women act as the initiatory, yet protectively maternal sexual partners to children. The children, in revolt, have condemned their parents to death for depriving them of self-expression and sexual freedom; they create a society in which fairies and …

posts._title: Shuji Terayama – Saraba Hakobune aka Farewell To The Ark (1984)
posts.title: Saraba Hakobune
posts.excerpt: In a tale that is visually stunning in certain segments, director Shuji Terayama (who died before this movie was released) has woven a spell of magic and social reprobation around the forbidden love of two cousins. posts.title: Ikiru
posts.excerpt: REVIEW:Shan Jayaweera, Senses of Cinema Along with the various uses of time and perspective in the narrative, Ikiru displays all the other hallmarks that make Kurosawa such an important and influential filmmaker.
